awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Confirming and Characterizing Transiting Exoplanets around Bright Stars with Ultra-precise Ground-based Photometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Many extra-solar planets ("exoplanets") are discovered today by tracking precisely the light from the star they orbit. When the planet transits, or passes in front of, the star, a tiny bit of the star's light is blocked. This allows astronomers to determine many properties of the planet. The PI's team are pioneers in using an optical device called an Engineered Diffuser. This device significantly reduces sources of uncertainty in the light output of the star, especially the effect known as scintillation ("twinkling," in a layperson's term). They will use this technique to identify, confirm, and study planets down to Earth's size around bright stars. They will also use the technique to study the stars' magnetic fields by detecting spots analogous to sunspots on the surface of the stars. Undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral associate, will take part in the observations and data analysis. The collaborators will also incorporate the results into their teaching and public outreach at their institutions.

Ground-based observations are subject to a number of limitations in their precision due to the day-night cycle, atmospheric effects, scintillation, transparency variations, differential extinction, seeing, and telescope-guiding effects which typically prevents them from achieving the photometric precision of space-based missions. The larger field of view offered by small aperture telescopes enables bright comparison stars to be more readily found, however, the aforementioned challenges often prevent small telescopes from matching space-based photometric precision. Larger telescopes offer better averaging of scintillation. The group's implementation of diffuser-aided photometry from the ground provides an improvement in performance compared to de-focused small telescopes and they have demonstrated on-sky photometric performance that rivals that of space telescopes at a fraction of the cost.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has realized the potential of novel Engineered Diffusers technology in enabling very high precision ground based photometry, at precision rivaling space, to enable studies in the field of Astronomy spanning exoplanet discovery and characterization to a better understanding of starspots. 

 

Intellectual Merit: By spreading out the starlight on the detector very deterministically these diffusers enable very precise photometry on an easily accessible and usable ground based telescope. This project has enabled the discovery  and confirmation of a number of new giant exoplanets orbiting M dwarfs (GEMS),  discovery of additional non-transiting planets by observing timing variation of transits, and the detailed characterization of starspots by using the shadow cast by a planet as it transit as a probe of the stellar surface. The project has also enabled the training and mentoring of a number of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students who have gone on to successful positions in academia and industry. Over a dozen referred publications, and multiple PhD theses in the field of Astronomy & Astrophysics have resulted as a direct outcome of this project.

 

Broader Impact: For many students working on this project has highlighted the interplay between technology and discovery in astronomy, encouraging them to work at this interface. Open dissemination of the technology and its use, and collaborating with other teams in enabling them to also use these diffusers with their own telescopes has popularized this, enabling both professionals and mature astronomers to use these tools. The project has also successfully built collaboration and exchanges between 4-year liberal arts education colleges, Universities, and federal research centers.  Discoveries from this project have led to both press releases and in engaging the public on exoplanet discovery and characterization.
